document.docAuthor: Wittmann, Karl J., Ariani, Antonio P. & Daneliya, Mikhail
document.masterDocTitle: The Mysidae (Crustacea: Peracarida: Mysida) in fresh and oligohaline waters of the Mediterranean. Taxonomy, biogeography, and bioinvasion

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Mysidae (Crustacea: Peracarida: Mysida) in fresh and oligohaline waters of the Mediterranean. Taxonomy, biogeography, and bioinvasion

bibRefCitation.author: Stammer
bibRefCitation.refString: Stammer, H. - J. (1933) Einige seltene oder neue Hohlentiere. Zoologischer Anzeiger, Suppl., 6, 263 - 266.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
6 F ad. 10.4â€“12.8 mm , mostly incubating nauplioid larvae, 1 F subad. 12.0 mm, 1 F imm. 9.7 mm , 1 M ad. 8.9 mm , plus fragments of 2 M ad. and 2 imm., subterranean freshwater lake in the karstic cave Donja Vjetrenica , 42.85N 017.98E , Herzegovina ,
Sept. 1960
, leg. B. Sket , BUL
; 5 F ad. 9.9â€“11.1 mm , mostly incubating nauplioid larvae, 1 F subad. 10.6 mm , 2 M ad. 9.4â€“9.9 mm , sampling data as above, 26 Sept. 1964 , BUL; 1 M ad. 11.9 mm in 2 parts, sampling data as above, Oct. 1986 , BUL; 1 M ad. 12.5 mm , completely dissected and mounted on slides, freshwater lake in same cave, Sept. 1981 , leg. A. P. Ariani; 1 M ad. 10.6 mm , fresh-water in same cave, 4 Aug. 2000 , leg. B. Trontelj, BUL.

Short diagnosis.
Troglomysis
without eye pigment in both sexes, also body without any pigment ( Fig. 7 C). Apical segment is 6â€“9% total length of antennal scale ( Fig. 18 D). Total length of thoracic endopods, and of their carpopropodus, in particular, decreases strongly in series of endopod 3 to 7, and following this increases strongly to endopod 8; carpopropodus 3â€“8 with 5â€“6, 5, 4, 3â€“4, 3â€“4, and 4â€“5 segments, respectively ( Fig. 18 Eâ€“K). Telson with 10â€“13 spines all along each lateral margin, not counting the pair of apical spines; small sinusoid cleft between the apical spines, cleft lined by 5â€“8 laminae ( Fig. 18 S, T).

Supplements and corrections to the description by Stammer (1936) . Rostrum forms a wide convex angle with broadly rounded tip ( Fig. 18 A). Eyestalks distally with external rudiments of cornea ( Fig. 18 B, C) visible in all specimens with eyes well preserved (n = 19; including the smallest one: immature female with 7.3 mm body length). Rudiments of cornea not drawn and not reported by Stammer. Antennal scale with small apical segment bearing five plumose setae ( Fig. 18 D). In contrast, Stammer drew and explicitely stated an unsegmented antennal scale. Flagellum 8-segmented in thoracic exopod 1, and 9-segmented in each of exopods 2â€“8 ( Fig. 18 L). Stammer figured the exopods 1, 2 correctly, but counted a surplus of one segment for each of exopods 1â€“8, obviously by considering the large intersegmental joint between basis and flagellum as a distinct segment. Outer distal corner of basis always well rounded ( Fig. 18 L). Thoracic endopods 3â€“8 ( Fig. 18 Eâ€“L): tarsus (carpopropodus plus dactylus) with 6â€“7, 6, 5, 4â€“5, 4â€“5, and 5â€“6 segments, respectively (Stammer reported only 5, 5, 4, 3, 3, and 5 "tarsal" segments, respectively, presumably by not counting the minute dactylus not mentioned by him); dactylus of endopods 3â€“7 with long, slender claw ( Fig. 18 Eâ€“J); dactylus 8 with very slender, seta-like claw ( Fig. 18 K) in both sexes; paradactylar setae with weak, one-sided armature of small barbs. The previously unknown paradactylar lobes ( Fig. 18 K) on endopod 8 represent an uncommon feature in Mysidae ; endopods 1â€“7 without such lobes ( Fig. 18 Eâ€“J). Scutellum paracaudale triangular with rounded tip, upper and lower margins inconspicuously undulate ( Fig. 18 Pâ€“R). Telson cleft is lined by laminae ( Fig. 18 S, T) rather than by spines as otherwise counted and drawn by
Stammer (1936: Fig. 17 )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 18.
Troglomysis
vjetrenicensis
Stammer, 1933
, from the cave Donja Vjetrenica (type locality). A, male with body length 9.9 mm, dorsal view on cephalothorax; B, left eye of male 12.5 mm, dorsal; C, right eye of female 12.0 mm, dorsal; D, antennal scale of male 12.5 mm; Eâ€“K, series of tarsi of thoracic endopods 3â€“8 in same male, setae omitted; L, eighth thoracopod with penis of same male; Mâ€“O, series of third to fifth pleopods in same male (M, O, views on outer = rostral face; N, inner = caudal face); Pâ€“R, posterior margin of sixth pleonite (lateral aspect turned by 90Â° to the left) in female 10.2 mm (P), female 10.4 mm (Q), and male 12.5 mm (R); S, telson of male 12.5 mm; T, distal third of telson in subadult female 12.0 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Statoliths ( Fig. 11 B) composed of fluorite, diameter 96â€“157 Âµm; statolith formula 2 + (2â€“3) + (0â€“2) + (8â€“13) + (7â€“12) = 19â€“30. General form discoid, maximum height only about 50-70% maximum width. Flattened ellipsoidal in lateral view, subcircular in ventral view. Fundus and ambitus ventrally forming together a weakly vaulted structure.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Occurrence ( Fig. 12 ). Only known from subterranean freshwater lakes and canals in the karstic cave Vjetrenica, one of the world's highest biodiversity cave systems ( Culver & Sket 2000 ), 42.85N 017.98E , near the village Zavala in the karstic plain Popovo polje, Herzegovina , 12 km from the coast of the Adriatic Sea. Type locality is the Donje jezero ( Lower Lake ) within the Donja Vjetrenica ( Lower Vjetrenica ) in this system. According to
Stammer (1936)
this lake is
234 m above sea level
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comparison. Already Stammer (1936) postulated some similarity but not a close relationship to the genus
Diamysis Czerniavsky, 1882
. Ariani (1979) noted that certain
Diamysis
from the Adriatic basin share with
Troglomysis
(referring to Stammerâ€™s description) the highest numbers of carpopropodal segments (three or five, respectively) in thoracic endopods 3, 4, and 8, in contrast to fewer in endopods 5â€“7. Most of our new data make this morphological similarity appear closer: antennal scale with apical segment bearing five setae, and sinus of telson without spines but with laminae. However, the lobes flanking the dactylus of the eighth thoracic endopods represent a newly discovered feature (besides the already known ones), supporting the status of
Troglomysis Stammer, 1933
, as a separate genus.
